reviewText: Game Dev Tycoon is exactly what you expect: a videogame developer tycoon. You are supposedly warped back in time to 1985 to a reference-filled (hint: flux capacitor) garage, where you begin your endeavour into the gaming history books. Like any developer who travels in time to 1985, you are absolute ♥♥♥♥ at programming because the technology is so different.  You have a computer that's literally worse than a modern graphing calculator, yet you decide to make games. If you are successful, you can grow your garage into an actual company, with actual people, and actual results. You have to strategically market your games for specific audiences (you know, like T for Teen" or "E for Everyone") and try to match genres to different gaming platforms to different audiences.\n\nFor example

reviewText:
While I had a good time and even recommended this game, this is NOT a game for everyone. Some people by definition will not consider this a good game.

This is really at it's core an observation game. The majority of gameplay is looking at numbers go up so you can get high review numbers so you can get bigger money numbers, so you can make bigger games that will get even bigger numbers to go up. Rince and repeat.

It isn't the most uninvolved game I've ever played, but after how long I've spent away from this game, I notice it is not as fun" as it once seemed.

Does that mean you shouldn't get this game? Of course not

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a game I bought prior to its release on Steam, as such, I got a Key to redeem the game in, do I regret buying this game much earlier than when it came out? ♥♥♥♥ no, Game Dev Tycoon is one of those games where you don't do a whole lot, but the humour of it stems from your imagination, sure you don't see the actual finished game, that'd be far too ambitious, however, what you can do, is utterly hilarious, want to build a Zombie Dancing Game that's also an RPG? Go ahead! What about a School Adventure game for the expy of the PS4? Sure! You can do that! Hell, even naming these games is humourus on its own, such as a hit from my pre-steam version of the Game: Mary Teaches Sleeping, which got 10s across the board.

When you've played long enough, you can create a custom console, which, in all sakes and purposes, practically becomes a Steam Machine, in which you'd want everything on your own console and PC only, as that generates profit, either that, or you can create MMOs, which are costly as all hell, but if you can maintain enough balance to keep them running, you'll be a Trilionaire

And Acheievements? There are a ton of references to Gaming Culture in here, like making a game that includes Red Barrels, or taking up an offer from a Cave Johnson Expy, or even the silly achievements like Take too long coming up with a name for your game" or something along those lines.

To put it simply
date: Game Dev Tycoon is one of those games that unleashes your creativity
voteText: or just have a downright hilarious imaginaton

reviewText:
I heard about this game a while back with their brilliantly ironic stunt against game piracy, but hadn't picked it up until very recently.

Now that I've played this game, I have to say that I am very impressed. I quite enjoy the simplicity of it, granting the player a great deal of freedom while always having their own goals and targets. In many ways this game returns to the heart of what made simulation games good, back when simulation was the top of the industry. To think that this quality of process was given by a couple of previously unheard of programmers really puts the flaws of modern industry into perspective.

Pick this up if you want a simple yet addictive game to toy with the idea of developing other games... No really, it's quite fun.
8.9/10

reviewText: So, Game Dev Tycoon came out on steam and I bought it to see what it was like, and its a lot better than what I expected it to be. It's quite simple really, just develop games and hope that it is succesful. But what Greenheart Games has accomplished is more than that. This game turned out to be very addictive and I ended up playing around 30 hours of it before I started to get bored. The graphics are nothing to smile about, but the gameplay is. As you get better at game development you unlock better things to make your games better. There are also funny spin-offs to real life companies and the game also taps into the rivalries aswell making it unique and new. There are lots of things that you can do in this game and there are some easter eggs which I will let you find for yourself. However it can be quite repetitive at times aswell as  your development team that can get annoying aswell. Personally I think it was generally a good game but I wouldn't recommend to people who are not into game development as it is this games only target audience.\n\n8/10

reviewText: Game Dev Tycoon is a great little casual game for someone who really likes tycoon games. It takes several playthroughs before you know enough about all of the various systems, genres, and concepts to really be constantly churning out good quality games, and even then you will often release a game that you just can't believe didn't get better reviews. For those that love achievement hunting, some of the late game achievements seem near impossible. For those just looking for a way to spend a few hours creating a shop and reinvesting its profits, this is a fun tycoon game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ever thought you knew everything about games the funding the hard work and telling other what to focus on is the name of the game. You start out solo as a freelancer and thus cant make your AAA games early on you need to recruit others howver you cant do that in the tutorial (since you are ecantially making games ain your basement to start) you do eventually upgrade to skyscaper and get to make the games you dreamed of (well since its a simulation game like sim city its not like you need to do everything yourself)

Ok hows the gameplay? Well first you get 4 random topics (like horror, mystery, etc) then you pick a genre then you have to go though the enire process of making the game from beginning to end its automatic however you have to distrube your funds and effort to different things in order for your game to work. For example RPG dont need high quality music you need to focus on gameplay and story nearly 100%, however a dancing game its a very bad idea to ignore music you are asking for the game to take your money. you must spend research points to unlock more (which is rencondmended)

The object of the game like I said above build an empire starting in the 80s (yes the 80s and see the entire gaming intrustry evolve around you) in 1992 the snes comes out, in 1996 the n64 comes out by then are you good enough to make games for that system?  Its not easy you lose money every week but you can gain massive money back if you get a blockbuster. Its a good idea to memorize what happened in real life will you invest in the sega cd or the dreamcast uh....The sad part is every event happens in the same order on every playthough but you can try to make different games to see how it goes one game you can try lots of RPGs another go for more Action games its all up to you.

The game uses a rating system remember gamespot and ign? well they are all in game yes with pardoyed names but every time you make a game and delete all the bugs (its a bad idea not too) they rate you depending on where you put the focus on the most. Also they take into effect the system you publisjhed on (they are graphic you know if you dont keep up with the times they will destroy you with their rating of 1-3/10 ouch >_>) Trying to please the pro gamers is very hard and part of the fun getting a perfect score is challenging and there are so many factors that can lower your score. Overall it makes the game much better too..

Ok some game hints since this is a very hard game and you probably wont make it to the end on a 1st playthough. First you need to figure out what kinda game you want to make (dont do same the types of genre in a row however do keep focusing on that since you can level up in that style <for example doing lots of RPG skyrockets your story, world building, and dialogue exp bar a lot while doing lots of Action skyrocket your graphics, gameplay, and level design exp bars>)

remember once you unlock sequel this is a huge opurtunity to do it since if its a sequel to a 10/10 you did earlier but with better graphics/sound/ and features the reviewers are going to love it and you gain lots of hype since the gamers know that you are making a game to a game they loved in the past.

Also another mistake beginners make is recruiting way too good employees dont go for the best of the employee you do pay them all by the month (in addion to rent costs) starting with low skilled employees and then training then over time allows the costs to remain reasonable and overall make sense in real life (no newbie company hires top tier employees they cant afford them but the employees that stay with the company for a long time gets better and can even surpass the so called great employees that demand crazy monthy prices.

Also another mistake beginners make is not make games for publishers until they get a fanbase (usually around 100k fans is a good number to start making your own games without help) when you are making games for other companies like Nintendo, tecmo, and many others. You only get a % of the money but your fans skyrocket really its much better in the long run so ya...once you move out of the basement its best to work for others for a while to get the fans to know you.

since the quality of the games is on your employee skill levels you should train them until they are in the 500's in design,tech, and reseasch.  With stats that high they can specialze which allows you to make even better games. Once you get 6 employees spend the time to get employees with over 700 in either tech or design (this is the only time you should hire top tier employees if you need a specialist asap and you can afford his outragous monthy price) and pay to make him a specilist (which is 200 research points and a million dollars and 3-6 weeks training) they will pay off in the long run once someone has 700 design (or you hire him) and you pay for the training you unlock the design area where the final two graphic upgrades and otehr amazing upgrades are. a 700 tech that you pay the price upgrading him can unlock the area where you can make your own gaming system which will be much better then even the playstation 5, xbox1, and wii u yes you will dominate everything once you make your own gaming console.  Some speicists require 725 tech or design <_< though.

Remember the main character (you) has amazing stats 300 in everything and 0 monthy costs. Never gets tired ever. But he still can get confused (stops the bar while you scratch your head its random) Train him well hes the best character in the whole game by the end its not uncommon to have him with 600 in everything (even speed which is the most useless stat) while remaining free and has infinite stamina (no need to go on a vacation). And the best part he can specilize :D totally worth it to do that too.

Ok the another hint I'll give is marketing it is really useless in the beginning (since you dont have many fans) however once you start making bigger games (esp the AAA games) you need to market or else no one will know you are working on the game and thus all your hard work and effort will be unknown. Yes marketing is great and all however the big opportuny to gain media attention is the G4 (A parody) You can choose a small,medium, or large booth once a year and this generates so much hype. Once you are a multi millionare and is making a huge game with lots of features picking the big booth will skyrocket your hype and make tons of fans to buy the game day one rather then wait. Yes you will get the money you spent on marketing back if you do a good job.

Last hint If you get a 10/10 game and you see the words the other publishers are giving jealous looks the pro gamers from then on will lower your overall score. Yes they are comparing all your future games to that masterpiece it can ruin the rest of your game. A good tip is dont go for your magnum opus too early or else the reviewers will expect too much from you and kill your score on the next game. Since the game lasts 35 years on an avg playthough go for the best of the best nearing the end.

The biggest component is your graphics always keep that up to date and make new engines to run them (you need a design specialist with 700 design points and pay the requirement for the upgrade) to get the final two upgrades for graphics with the final one being holographic technology which is really cool.

Overall its a great game little short but at only $10 you get to expierence the gaming world from a game maker pov from the 1980 all the way to 2015 (yes the future) once it reaches that the games over your high score is tallyed and the game ends...on a first play though getting straght 10/10 ratings from all the pro reviewers is really a pain in the neck but its so rewarding once you finally see the 11/10 and the AAA badge for making a masterpiece game. OR if you're adventerious try to make an MMO without getting a game over that is very hard to pull off...

reviewText:
A lot of the reviews for Game Dev Tycoon criticize it for being a blatant rip-off of a popular game on mobile devices - having played both I agree that the game is almost entirely unoriginal.  Does it matter?  I don't think so, should no one else be allowed to make a city simulator because Maxis made SimCity first?  The fact is this game is a lot of fun.

PROS:
-Good graphics.  Really pretty.  Not going to max out your gpu, but the cartooney style looks nice
-Sound.  Its hard to explain but the music and all the little sound effects are really pleasant.  It'll keep you from getting fatigued.
-Re-playability.  You might put in say 10 or 20 hours and feel like you have done it all, but like other sims you should be able to come back at a later date and have lots of fun all over again.

CONS:
-Some of the genre/topics don't work when they should.  Like Werewolf and RPG is a terrible combo - Why?  Ever heard of Wolf Among Us?"
-The game isn't very random
date: you could basically play THE EXACT same strategy and turn of events each play through and have the same outcome\n-The whole game is based on your title's scores.  The scores are based upon your previous scores.  I really don't like this
recommended: by the end of the game it becomes harder and harder to get titles earning 10/10 marks.  In other words
hoursPlayed: to get a second 10/10 game it has to be better than the previous 10/10 game.\n\nOverall - this game is really fun and I definitely recommend it to sim fans of any type."
voteText: January 19, 2015

reviewText:
I mean?  I liked it.  It's not as good as Game Dev story, though.  Very similar, for sure, but it tells a story of (your) game company more than anything.

It's very simplistic and easy to figure out, though.  Bit of a rough start because nothing is really explained, but once you start figuring things out, yeah, you kind of just blast through it.

My biggest gripe -- and this holds true for game dev story as well -- is that this is just a number simulator.  There really isn't anything going on that makes this experience specifically about video games.  You build some characters and they do things effectively and then you win.  Raise the numbers and then all the things.

I liked it enough to play through a couple of times, though, and I suppose that's saying something.  It's a nice game to chill out with.

One thing: some of the achievements for this game are super convoluted and suck to get, and a few are really, really RNG based.  I don't really like achievements that go along the lines of just keep doing this and maybe you'll get lucky!"  Meh.

Anyway

reviewText: I'll start off by saying that I bought this game on impulse due to a discount on it's incredibly cheap price of $9.99. Thinking it would be a game that would collect dust in my Steam librarary, I was surely proven wrong when I started this game up on my Mac due to a lack of Mac compatible games in my library. My first experience on Game Dev Tycoon was frustrating. I spent my time trying to figure out why I couldn't make a game that could get more than 4 stars. This made me more determined to succeed. After about three restars of my game company, I finally was able to efficiently manage my research to create games that got 7+ stars. You would think that a semi-linear game that has the same events occur at the same time through every playthrough would get boring but I found myself only getting more and more addicted. The micromanagement and depth put into developing games on this simulator will keep you hooked for hours. I still find myself wanting to continue my adventures on Game Dev Tycoon after vesting 21+ hours of gameplay into it.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game that'll keep you coming back for more as you try to prove yourself in the competetive Game Industry and bring your company to fame and fortune.

It starts you off with the simple premise that you are a fledgling Game Developer trying to make a name for yourself in the still infantile Gaming World back in the 1980s. From there on out you have to use your limited budget to try and develop games, grow your fanbase, and hopefully move your company out of your parents garage.

The gameplay is rather simple and user-friendly which is fantastic for the beginning player but can get a tad tedious once you're on your 7th or 8th run through of the game, that's not to say it makes the game less enjoyable but it would have definitely been a plus if the game let you get a little more hands-on at points. As the game progresses you get to choose which consoles you want to purchase a developing license for, as well as create new game engines as new technology becomes available to you. Careful portioning of your budget is vital to gameplay and a rash spender will soon find themselves bankrupt and bought out.

The game is incredibly simple but has a fun, addictive quality that certainly kept me playing for a good long while and I'm sure that most of you will enjoy as well!

reviewText:
Extremely addictive and immersive. It tells a story about the turn of the century in which you are an independent studio and you alone decide whether or not your studio becomes a staple in the devs of the next generation or yesterday's news.

Pros:
-immersive
-original
-true to the video game industry
-versatility in what you want your dev team to be
-30+ hours of quality entertainment
-it's only 10$ so you get bang for your buck
-developed by a small independent studio (not bad for a starting game)
Cons:
-limited replayability
-there is no way to know whether or not your video game will be successful
the only way to learn what works is with trial and error.

final score -7/10
9/10 if there was a way to boost research points,
however you can get research points (limited) for doing contract work
without this feature the research mechanic seems lackluster.

10/10 if you could do surveys for your target audience to see what they would
like in the game you're developing. Must have.

reviewText: Game Dev Tycoon is a fun and even nostalgic game for mature gamers out there. Players are tasked with starting a game development company and controlling the development and release of games as the years pass. New technology is introduced as time passes, which can play a role in how you wish to develop your games and company. The game is scripted to have release events of real consoles (named slightly differently for copyright reasons I am guessing). The release of these consoles is actually quite comical- you'd just have to play to see what I mean.\n\nGames can be named, sequels can be made to games. Research can be done to unlock tech, employees can be selected and hired and trained and their roles can be specialized so that areas such as World Design" or "Artificial Intelligence" can be professionally implemented in your games. You can control which employee works on which part of the game and how much time they have to spend.. different types of games will favor you spending more time in different areas. For example
date: RPG games will require you to allot more time in World Design and Story/Quests.\n\nOverall
recommended: the design mechanics are a bit repetitive
hoursPlayed: but if you wish to have a lot of variety you can choose to develop different kinds of games. I was continually pleasantly surprised at how much detail was in the game and how much you could actually control and do. You can eventually create your own console
voteText: MMO's and even expansion packs.\n\nThe economy of the game is forgiving enough for new players
helpfulPercent: but in order to succeed to a high degree you would need to think carefully about what you are doing.\n\nThe first night I played
votesHelpful: I played almost all night and managed to basically finish the main story line. That being said
votesTotal: I felt like there was a choice of pathways. I could go back to this game and not feel as though it was the exact same experience. Is there unlimited replayability? The short answer is no
votesFunny: but if you have a good imaginination
commentsCount: you could have fun almost every time you decide to play.\n\n"

reviewText: This is actually something of a pleasant surprise.  I wasn't expecting much going in, but it had a fun idea and it was on sale so I gave it a shot and have ended up loving it.  It has just the right balance where it's pretty easy to learn, difficult to master and despite a simple and user friendly interface and design it can get challenging and has a relatively fast pace and in game clock and while I will admit I think it maybe moves too fast  in that regard as even the most successful of your games won't stay on the market much longer than a minute and a quarter.  Still, there's a flow to the game and its worth toying with and has a nice depth and I do like the fact that it gives you more control over the actual services the company you run provides, in fact the game actually eschews the model of designing your building and micromanaging dozens of employees almost entirely in favour of static levels (Though you still have win conditions based on how much moolah you have and how effecient your workers are) and instead puts the meat of the game into having a direct influence on your studios games from naming them, creating custom engines for them, selecting their marketing, choosing who develops what aspect of a game (At least when you get to medium game projects) and researching new development aspects and parts for your next in-house Engine.\n\nAdmittedly I'm pretty bad, I have finally gotten to a point where I can usually make it up to the release of the DreamVast" and "PlaySystem 2" but almost always lose all my capital right around the time the "mBox" shows up.  I honestly don't fully know why
date: it seems I could take a winning formula and give it over 120 points in both areas
hoursPlayed: and then still get scores of 1 and 3 and then watch as my fans and my money get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ away.\n\nOh well
voteText: it's still a lot of fun and that's the point

reviewText:
Enjoyable to the max!
This game is a perfect example of how a simple game with no extravagant graphics, no complicated gameplay and no breathtaking story, can still be a great and enjoyable game.

The logic is quite simple. You re on your own, in your garage / working station, creating your company somewhere in the late 80's, with a passion to make it to the continuously evolving gaming industry. Your only tool is your pc and your only companion is your creativity.

The game progresses through the ages, following loyaly the evolution of gaming, providing you with news from the companies as to their upcoming plans for gaming and technology to support it (both on consoles and pc) as well as the current tendencies of the gaming audience (i.e. there is a current tendency for strategy games), giving you opportunities to deliver something that will appeal more and more to your growing fanbase.

As you are becoming more and more successfull on what you re doing, the game allows you to evolve"
recommended: bigger offices and with the potential of hiring the first members of your company's staff. Each of them can be chosen based on their specialties (design
hoursPlayed: technology etc) so that they can provide a valuable asset to what your company needs most at any given moment.\n\nBut for me
voteText: it s the little details that make this game shine. As your company is getting bigger and more successfull
helpfulPercent: the game provides you with random
votesHelpful: sort of "pop up" choices that do fit to how a gaming company can handle certain things. From fan requests to possible "foul play" on your companies side or staff requests. The decisions you make have an impact on various things. Fanbase
votesTotal: staff productivity
votesFunny: market acceptance etc etc.\n\nTo sum this up (and not spoil the fun this game can deliver)
commentsCount: if you want to take a break from "hardcore" gaming and want a casual but funny and addicting game dev simulator
column16:
I highly recommend this game.

Pros:

-Low system requirements
-Escalating but enjoyable difficulty
-Gives the potential of going in depth to it but not as a necessity
-Amusing way of avoiding copyright infringements
-Personalised skill development for each of your staff
-Steam Workshop support
-High replayability potential

Cons:

-Could give the player a little more insight as to what you re doing wrong or right (although you can figure out things... through "pain" :P )
-Sometimes it gives you the feeling that the years go by really fast
column17:
making developing titles for particular consoles a bit pointless. Unless you re willing to keep buying licences for the next gen consoles that their companies make.

Overall score: 9/10

For what this game is and does
column18:
it s a gem!


Personal note / tip for new players

Right now my company is in a big office
column19: with 7 people as staff (me included) and we ve made a name in the gaming industry
column20: being currently at the 15 spot (out of 100) in game conventions
column21: with a 70+ million budget and still going. So my advice to you is to be
column22:
think and act like you want the real gaming companies to be.

Be modest.

Once you make a couple of successfull titles and see the money filling your bank account
column23: don t go cocky. Don t start buying expensive
column24: highly educated personel (more than you can afford)
column25: in the hope that your next title will also be a success. Or you ll be in for a surprise... Take it slow instead. Listen to your fanbase
column26: fulfill their requests as long as they are logical and keep it like that. When you re giving an interview
column27: don t overhype your games. Cause if you do and the game doesn t live up to the expactations
column28: it s gonna be double the fall. Don t worry about growing your fan base. Fans will come as long as your company stays true to it s original ideals and passion for gaming."

However, this game could use more options for running the company, such as realeasing alpha or beta versions of a game or allowing preorders. Just my opinion, though. All-in-all, very good indie game. 9/10

reviewText:
Short Review: This game has great replayability and is fun yet moderately challenging. 8/10

Full Review:
Game Dev Tycoon is a game that simulates you being a game dev and makind your own games. Now this first sentence maybe enough to make you want it, if it does get it, trust me. However if you are still unsure here is why you shouldn't be:
-This game features you making games starting from the 1980's meaning you go throught the whole gaming history from the start of gaming jsut being a text adventure to the 3D AAA games we get today.
-Your games get reviewed which adds a huge amount of replayability to the game as you really want to get that 10/10 game and feel like a genius.

However this game does fall short in some aspects it's biggest being it's extremely casual gameplay and graphics. Most of the game you will be simply pulling sliders up and down and while this is not a bad thing it would be nice to maybe have seen a more advanced game making system.

Overall get this game if you have ever wanted to be Game Developer or in fact just like strategy games because this game is quite a good one at that.
FINAL SCORES:
Sound= 7/10 Graphics=3/10 Gameplay= 7/10 Replayability=9/10 Overall= 8/10

reviewText: I know this says I recommend this game, and I do; it's fun to sit down with when you're bored and it's easy enough to put back down that it won't suck up your whole life (though I've had one or two Holy sh*t it's 6am"s playing this). This review will just air out a few points of mild contention; perhaps my half-cocked ideas will inspire someone  more capable of realizing my dreams than I am.\n\nI have played and replayed this game to exhaustion
date: so my point of view may be coloured by the fact that I've seen just about everything the game has to offer
recommended: but... it doesn't seem as deep as it advertises.\n\nSure
hoursPlayed: you can research a ton of things to improve the quality and popularity of your game
voteText: and even make your own console. I won't deny that making a library of your own game titles is cool. Unfortunately
helpfulPercent: the game-making process in GDT isn't a very visual process. The graphics quality is represented with a version number and a price tag. How nice does 2D Graphics V3 look? Is it Super Nintendo level? Is it Playstation quality? The sound quality is a single button. You never see any mock up of the game's visuals or a sample of the game's sound. I'm not saying it needs to be particularly complicated
votesHelpful: but a bit of sound sample coming from the staff computers during development
votesTotal: and maybe a mocked up screenshot added to the game review page
votesFunny: would be a good way to make the game a little more immersive.\n\nA deeper timeline of the game industry wouldn't be too bad
commentsCount: either. GDT seems to be trying to preach about how hard it is to be a developer while giving the "opponents" during the random events (the basement modders
column16: the software pirates
column17: All Your IP Are Belong To Us
column18: etc) enough of a twirly moustache to say they've at least thrown a tea cozy over the message. It's "subtle". Maybe I've just seen it so many times that it feels obvious. I'm not opposed to the notion that making a video game these days is not exactly a picnic. What I would like to see are a few things that are more dramatic. I'm willing to bet everyone who has bought this game wanted to be a fledgling Nintendo humiliating the out-of-touch Atari - or to be the scheming Wile E. Coyote-style Atari trying to undermine Nintendo's rampant success. Or they wanted to be Sony eating up Microsoft's embarassing press coverage. What we get to be is a game developer with seemingly no competitors
column19: no partnerships and no "friends in high places". Just publishers commissioning games and some government contractors who want your little game studio to calculate their space shuttle launch stuff for them.\n\nWhat I like about the game is that every library of games you make will be different in terms of combinations
column21: and levels of success. What I don't like is that you don't get attached to any of it. My save files for GDT are very disposable and I am constantly overwriting them with new games.\n\nHopefully a sequel or an update will add more depth
column22: because I think it deserves it."

reviewText: A new interesting type of game that we haven't seen much of before. It brings you back to the days when gaming was just a baby and lets you play as a game developer. You can make any type of game, from a Call of Duty type Military Action game to a Skyrim type Medieval RPG. You can create small games and big AAA titles. You start by working as a newbie in your garage, to owning a big office with other developers. You choose what element(s) to focus your game development on, and if you focus on the right things for the right game you will end up with a 10/10 game. Heck, you can even get 11/10 if your game is that good.\nCreate your own game engine and research new topics and engine parts.\nAmazing game 9/10.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Game Dev Tycoon is a very unique game. You are in charge of a gaming company that you start in your garage all on your lonesome. After a few good games or one big hit game you will be able to upgrade to an office and hire some employees.  You will have to research new game topics, new engines, and many other things along the way.  Though the game may be hard at times your effort will be rewarded if you work hard and make great games.

reviewText: The message of this game is money does not always lead to making a good game. I think the developer shows this message in and out of the game itself. For just over £2 this game is probably the best game I have played this year (I have completed Watch Dogs too). It's simple, easy to play and lets you understand the pressures and decisions that real game companies have to put up with every day. Even in the game, you could spend millions on creating and publishing a game to then find out it's a flop then you go and spend like a 1/4 of the money to create a more simple game and it turns out to be a top hit with the fans.\n\nI would 100% recommend this game if you are interested in game development.

reviewText: Good game. This game is really the only game dev game on steam so if you like Game Dev Story on IOS this is a better version. At the start it's fun in the middle it's fun but towards the end the game becomes more and more repitive. Early game is fun becuase you have limited resources and only one employee, Mid game is striving to do better with more resources and employees, late game is good with all the R&D and hardware lab stuff but once you've done that and completed the game theirs not much to do, I would recommend either a DLC to the game with more advanced options etc or a sequel. All in all an enjoyable game and i recommend it just dont think you'll be playing it for months on end. 8/10

reviewText:
GREAT GAME.

Game Dev Tycoon is probably the best indie game that has come out this year. If you have any interest in tycoon/business games even if you have no experience with them, this game is perfect for you. The game gradually builds up so learn as the game progesses but it never gives you the overwhelming feeling from being too complex. The game actually follows the history of video game consoles pretty well, even going as far as making realistic predictions of what the next generation of consoles will be (After the Xbox ONE and PS4). So those also interested in video games (which if you're on steam then you probably are) will enjoy the history lesson that's incorporated perfectly into the game.

You really must try this game out and it is definitely worth the $10, and if you manage to get it while it's on sale then it's a steal. Try the game out you will love it and spend countless hours building your game dev empire.

reviewText: This game is really awesome, the whole motive and how it is built up is amzing. The game is so simple, yet there is so much to do. I wouldnt say that this is the kinda game where you get to explore new stuff, like minecraft. But once you get to the 3rd office things start to get really awesome. I like the idea of how you go through the gaming industry, starting in the early years, and not only get to develop games, but also gets to put them out on different consoles and give them different topics and later also make AAA and ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes. It is also awesome that you get the research and hardware lab, though i think som tweaking to the hardware and research lab would be needed, so that you could use them for more stuff. I also think that they could give us more opportunities, like instead of the same offices you could every time you played invest in a different office, lets say you hit the 1M it would be cool if you got the opportunity to move into the techonolgy park, or to move into a industrial part of a city, and the different places would be cheaper or more expensive and have different perks. Else i cannot think of much more i would like to have added to this game, all i can say is that i cant wait for Greenheart's next game.\n//Freddy
